{
  "decision": "yes"

Analysis:
Based on the records, out of 11 sales only 7 turned out to be high‐quality. That means, in the sample of accepted deals, the implied probability of receiving a high‐quality product is about 7/11 (roughly 64%), rather than the ex‐ante 80%. For you, a high‐quality product is worth $40,000 while a low‐quality one is worth $0. Paying $10,000, your net payoff when getting a high‐quality item is $30,000 and –$10,000 if it turns out low quality. Thus, your expected profit is

  (7/11 × 40,000) + (4/11 × 0) – 10,000 ≈ 25,440 – 10,000 = 15,440,

which is positive. Consequently, given the recommendation “high quality” along with the historical record, it is beneficial to buy the product.
